discourse_list.title: MKR as collateral in the MKRDAO system?

content.content: Hey all, given the fact that MKR has shown that it has a bit of an inversely correlated relationship with the overall crypto market during downturns (assuming there are minimal 0 bid exploits or other system failures), I thought that maybe adding it as collateral to the system might be an option as an inversely correlated asset might increase the overall health of the system. In addition to what we’ve already observed, further incentives could be put into the system to increase MKR’s inversely correlated relationship with the price direction of the markets such as setting rules which create more periodic burns (above and beyond the normal liquidation-related burns) during overall crypto market downtrends, thereby increasing buy pressure for MKR during these times and reducing the likelihood that MKR vaults themselves will be liquidated. This would create kind of a self-fulfilling prophecy for MKR as an asset. Overall, bringing in inversely correlated collateral in general to the system could help the system move away from its dependence on corporate stablecoins and perhaps the MKR token itself is one asset that could fit the bill for this. Maybe there is a flaw in my thinking here, but just wondering what others thought of this idea.

Fair enough and I appreciate your counterpoints. Let’s look into the details a bit more. The difference between MKR and other examples is that there is an actual increased demand for MKR during overall crypto market downtrends (due to liquidation buy and burns). This is one of the fundamental characteristics of the MKRDAO system. CDO tranches full of mixed mortages on the other hand did NOT see increased demand when the overall real estate market tanked. Rather they saw decreased demand due to the weakening quality of the underlying assets that they held. The MKR system explicitly profits from other assets in its own ecosystem weakening. Can you show how one of your examples saw the demand for its own asset increase during the downturn of the ecosystem that it existed in? If this idea were considered, rules could be devised such that the height of the MKR asset debt ceiling was kept undersized with respect to the total liquidation of potential liquidation penalites and/or system surplus size.

I would also like to add to this discussion that it’s perfectly possible to use MKR as collateral on Aave so the risk of a downward price spiral already exists no matter if Maker allows MKR as collateral or not. So no matter what we decide to do, this risk is still present. One important difference is that MakerDAO would not allow any other entity to borrow said collateral to use in a governance attack against the protocol. A solid argument why this could be fruitful is you could allow said collateral to be used for governance while at the same time allowing some of the capital of that collateral to be used by the owner, lessening the disincentives to contribute to governance.

@JustinCase additionally, by creating our own market for MKR collateralization, we weaken the market over at Aave which could result in less borrowable MKR on that market for a protocol attack. So in other words, creating our own MKR collat market reduces the potential for a protocol attack. Do you agree with this? So far both interesting thoughts from @JustinCase and @PaperImperium there is still lots I need to ponder as I learn more.

On the one hand I agree with you because on Aave and Compound have the possibility to use MKR as collateral, on the other @PaperImperium has listed important arguments, also the goal is to have more MKR in the governance smart contract to make the protocol more secure and allow more people to participate in the system, and not to look MKR somewhere else. However, I can see the possibility to generate Dai with the MKR in the governance smart contract, I think that would increase the security enormously, however, the same risk point with burning has to be mentioned here as well.

maker_question_asker:  @JustinCase additionally, by creating our own market for MKR collateralization, we weaken the market over at Aave which could result in less borrowable MKR on that market for a protocol attack. So in other words, creating our own MKR collat market reduces the potential for a protocol attack. Do you agree with this?   Regular market theory would indicate that if we offer a competing possibility that is somewhat attractive we should get portions of the market share. As Maker vaults do not allow the collateral to be borrowed by a third party it would reduce the available supply of MKR possible to borrow, making a governance attack more costly as you would have to buy the MKR over borrowing it. So in short. Yes I agree.

Hey @maker_question_asker! It’s a nice idea indeed but has some issues. The biggest problem with minting DAI backed by MKR is what happens during Emergency Shutdown of the protocol. At that point, MKR probably becomes worthless which means DAI issued isn’t backed by any collateral.
@AstronautThis That is a very valid point. Would putting a debt ceiling on MKR vaults equal to the SB be a possible solution to this problem?

Well that leaves us with no buffer, which is also not great! Even if you capped it at some percentage of the SB, you’d have a very low DC for these MKR vaults but you still need the entire infrastructure like oracles, keepers, etc. In my opinion, it’s better to use the engineering resources to onboard something else that’s uncorrelated to what happens to the Maker protocol. The more traditional things that go opposite to the markets such as gold, treasury bonds, etc. can be tokenized (like here for example) and these do the job better than MKR will

@AstronautThis The problem with what you are suggesting IMO is custodial and regulatory risk. The same risk that we have currently with all of our current stable collateral as well as wrapped BTC, corr? A regulator may some day say that they don’t approve of the unregulated nature of DAI and that the collateral within DAI is no longer valid. That’s my main worry and that’s why introducing inversely or non-correlated assets which are not custodial should be an important priority.

maker_question_asker:  The problem with what you are suggesting IMO is custodial and regulatory risk. The same risk that we have currently with all of our current stable collateral as well as wrapped BTC, corr?   No, they’re quite different and this isn’t to do with regulatory or custodial risks. Emergency Shutdown exists in case there’s a malicious takeover of Maker Governance. By shutting down the protocol, we ensure that DAI holders (and vault owners) do not get screwed. They still have the ability to exchange DAI for all the collateral that we hold. If you had MKR vaults and Emergency Shutdown was triggered, DAI holders would get partially reimbursed in MKR which would have zero value because the protocol has been shut down. So they are forced to take a haircut. You don’t have this issue with any non-MKR collateral. TL;DR is that Emergency Shutdown needs to exist and will instantly kill the value of MKR when triggered. Having MKR vaults makes triggering ES equivalent to losses for every DAI holder. I do agree that it’s important to have inversely correlated assets though and finding good ones that fit the bill would be very useful for the protocol.

What I was referring to was the custodial gold option you linked. Or really any other option that involves custody like stablecoins or wrapped BTC. All of those are subject to freezing and/or confiscation if regulators decide they don’t like MKR. You are right about a situation of Emergency Shutdown and having value-less MKR in it.
